title: Gordon’s gin, TINY jam sandwiches, and loads of HP sauce…this is what the Queen actually eats and drinks each day
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments WITH her string of lavish castles and residences, you may imagine the Queen enjoys fine dining and butler-served platters on a daily basis. 
But bowls of Special K cereal, fingers sandwiches and chocolate biscuits are the royal’s favourite, according to her former personal chef. Getty Images 7 You may expect the Queen to enjoy fine dining at all times, but that is not always the case 
According to former royal chef Darren McGrady, who became a personal chef to the Queen and later Diana, the queen “is not a foodie”. 
While she regularly enjoys lavish banquets during her numerous social events, at home she is a diner of simple tastes and selects her dishes on a daily menu, crossing out the option she doesn’t want. 
He said to the Telegraph : “She eats to live, unlike Prince Philip who loves to eat and would stand and talk food all day.” Getty Images 7 The Queen has a team to shop for her and is presented with a daily royal menu to choose from, but visited Waitrose in the past for an official visit 
But that hasn’t stopped her having some guilty pleasures, such as a gin before lunch, afternoon tea with finger sandwiches and a frequent supply of McVitie’s rich tea biscuits. 
But what else does her royal highness tuck into each day? Here we round-up the dishes that the Queen enjoys behind closed doors…. Breakfast 7 The Queen enjoys a brew of tea before breakfast accompanied with some biscuits 
In typical British fashion, the Queen starts her day with a pot of freshly brewed tea poured by a tail-coated footman. 
The beverage is served in a china cup with milk and no sugar, and accompanied by some biscuits. 
Like many households in the UK, she then enjoys a classic bowl of cereal – usually Special K – and a portion of fruit. 
Other cereals kept in the Royal Household include Kellogg’s, Weetabix, and Quaker Oats. 
Forget a staff member pouring the flakes out of the cardboard box, the Queen likes her Special K to be kept in Tupperware to keep it fresh. Getty Images Occasionally she will dine on toast and jam, which is bought from Wilkin & Sons Getty Images 7 She is a fan of Special K, but sometimes has scrambled eggs with smoked salmon and truffle 
Occasionally she will dine on toast and jam, which is bought from Wilkin & Sons, or on scrambled eggs with smoked salmon and truffle. 
Specifically, eggs must be bought from Noble Foods and have to be brown, as she believes they taste better, according to the Guardian , and expensive truffles were only to be eat at Christmas when gifted. 
According to BT , she typically takes her meal with the Duke of Edinburgh and sometimes her corgis in her private first-floor dining room, which overlooks the Palace garden. ONE HAS A BLUE TICK, YOU KNOW Queen offering £30,000 a year to run her official personal Twitter account Lunch 
The Queen is often a solitary lady who lunches, but her lady-in-waiting will sometimes be invited to join. 
Before she dines, she enjoys a tipple of gin and aperitif Dubonnet, served with a slice of lemon and ice. 
It is likely she takes Gordon’s Gin, which has a royal warrant, which is a supplied good to the Queen’s household. Getty Images 7 The palace has a number of royal warrants for condiments, including Lea & Perrins, HP Sauce, and Heinz ketchup 
Keeping with her simple dining theme, former chef McGrady revealed she likes grilled Dover sole with wilted spinach or courgettes, washed down by a glass of wine. 
Or alternatively, she sometimes opts for a simple grilled chicken with salad to help maintain her slim figure. 
McGrady told the MailOnline she has a no starch rule and doesn’t consume potatoes, rice or pasta. Afternoon tea 
The Queen enjoys four meals a day, including afternoon tea into her daily regime. 
The spread features finger sandwiches of smoked salmon, cucumber, egg and mayonnaise or ham and mustard – all with the crusts removed. 
She also enjoys jam pennies, which are mini jam sandwiches cut into circle shapes the size of pennies. 
Other nibbles, include McVitie’s rich tea biscuits and scones, along with a selection of her favourite cakes. 
These include ginger, fruit, honey and cream sponge and a chocolate biscuit cake that was served at Will and Kate’s wedding, according to McGrady. Dinner 
Meals for dinner follow a traditional “in season” English food theme, McGrady, who was trained at London’s prestigious Savoy Hotel, revealed. 
Meats that are served include beef, pheasant and salmon, all produced on Sandringham and Balmoral estates. Getty Images Meals for dinner follow a traditional “in season” English food theme and will typically include beef, venison, pheasant and salmon 
These are accompanied by mushroom sauce, cream and whisky. 
Owen Hodgson worked in the Palace in the early Nineties, revealed a palace secret to the Telegraph that mushrooms are always cooked in marmite. 
The palace has a number of royal warrants for condiments, including Lea & Perrins, HP Sauce, and Heinz ketchup. 
To wind up her day, the Queen enjoys a restorative glass of Champagne, most likely chosen from eight royal warrant brands – including Lanson, Krug and Bollinger. The Queen's former butler Paul Burrell shows how her majesty eats her bananas
